content.title: Percentage Change Using a Multiplier
content.content: Shopkeepers often need to increase or decrease the price of an item by a percentage. This is easily done using a multiplier.

content.title: Multiplier Examples
content.content: For example: if a price is increased by 20%, the final price is 100% + 20% or 120% of the original price, so the multiplier = 1.2. If a price is decreased by 20%, the final price is 100% - 20% or 80% of the original price, so the multiplier = 0.8.

content.question: What multiplier corresponds to: a) a 40% increase b) a 15% decrease?
For the following multipliers, state the corresponding percentage increase or decrease: a) 1.15 b) 0.88

solution.a: 1.15 = 1.15 x 100% = 115%, which is an increase over 100% of 15%
solution.b: 0.88 = 0.88 x 100% = 88%, which is a decrease below 100% of 12%

content.question: a) Increase $10,500 by 8%. b) Decrease 120 pounds by 12%.

solution.b: new amount = 88% of 120 pounds = 0.88 x 120 = 105.60 pounds

content.question: A house is bought for $156,000 and six months later is sold for $175,500. What is the percentage increase on the investment?

solution.method1: multiplier = new value / old value = 175500/156000 = 1.125 = 112.5%, so a 12.5% increase occurred

content.title: Mark-Up
content.content: In order to make a profit, a retailer must add on an amount to the price at which he or she buys goods. This amount is called the mark-up.

content.title: Mark-Up Example
content.content: For example, if the retailer buys an item for $100 and his mark-up is 40%, he will mark the item to sell at $100 x 140% = $140. The mark-up on the item is $40.

content.question: Alfred buys shirts for 20 euros and marks them up by 60%. At what price does he sell them?
content.solution: Alfred sells the shirts for 20 euros x 160% = 20 euros x 1.6 = 32 euros

content.title: Discount
content.content: DISCOUNT

content.question: Sally discounts her dresses by 20% at her annual sale. What is the sale price of a dress originally marked at $150?
content.solution: Sale price = original price x 80% = $150 x 0.8 = $120

content.question: A bag of tomatoes is sold at 4.35 euros to make a 30% profit. Find the cost price of the tomatoes.
content.solution: selling price = 130% of cost price, so 4.35 = 1.30 x cost price, therefore cost price = 4.35/1.30 = 3.35 euros

content.question: A local electrical store offers a 15% discount on all items sold at its summer sale. If a television set is sold for $675, find its marked price.
content.solution: Since there is a 15% discount, selling price = 85% of marked price, so $675 = 0.85 x marked price, therefore marked price = $675/0.85 = $794.12

content.title: Tax on the Sales of Goods
content.content: In most countries a tax is payable on the sale of goods. This tax has various names depending on the country where the transaction takes place. The two most common names are value added tax (VAT) and goods and services tax (GST).

content.title: Tax Rates by Country
content.content: The standard rate of tax varies from one country to another. For example: in Chile it is 19%, in the UK it is 17.5%, in Sweden it is 25%, in Russia it is 18%, in Australia it is 10%, in Singapore it is 7%.

content.question: In order to make reasonable profit, an electrical store in Russia must sell a television set for 8500 rubles. If an 18% tax applies, find: a) the television's selling price b) the amount of tax.

solution.b: The amount of tax = (10030 - 8500) rubles = 1530 rubles

content.title: Chain Percentage Problems
content.content: Sometimes we need to use a multiplier more than once within a problem.

content.question: A 1.25 L soft drink is bought by a deli for $0.90 (GST exclusive). The deli owner adds 70% mark-up and then 10% GST. What price does the customer pay?
Cucumbers are initially marked up 30% above the cost price. If a 10% discount is then offered, what is the percentage profit? Assume there is no VAT or GST.
content.solution: Selling price = cost price x 130% x 90% = cost price x 1.3 x 0.9 = cost price x 1.17 = 117% of cost price. So, the percentage profit is 17%.

questions.text: Find the multiplier that corresponds to:

A surfboard manufactured for $300 is sold to a retail shop for a 40% profit plus 10% VAT. How much does the retail shop pay?
Flavoured milk is sold to a supermarket for $1.20 per carton. The supermarket adds 60% profit plus 10% GST. What price does the customer pay?

A fisherman sells a crayfish to a wholesaler for 35 euros. The wholesaler sells it to a fresh fish shop for 60% profit. However, the fish shop is forced to sell the crayfish at a 15% loss. Assuming there is no tax, what price must a crayfish lover pay for this delicacy?
If bread is marked up 40% above the cost and then a 20% discount is offered, what is the percentage profit? Assume there is no tax.

A rare book is bought by an antiques dealer, and he marks its price up by 100% for sale. One of his regular customers is interested in buying the book, so the dealer offers the customer a 20% discount. What is the overall percentage profit on the sale?

content.title: Appreciation and Inflation
content.content: When the value of an investment or an item such as a house increases, we say it appreciates in value. You may have noticed that the prices of everyday goods and services also increase over time due to inflation. This is a form of appreciation.

content.question: The inflation rate over the next three years is predicted to be 2% then 3% then 3.5%. If an item currently costs $140 and the cost rises in line with the predicted inflation, what will its cost in 3 years' time be?
Over 4 consecutive years, the value of a house increases by 15%, increases by 9%, decreases by 4%, and increases by 18%. What is the overall percentage increase in value over this period?
content.solution: Let $x be the original value. value after 1 year = $x x 1.15, value after 2 years = $x x 1.15 x 1.09, value after 3 years = $x x 1.15 x 1.09 x 0.96, value after 4 years = $x x 1.15 x 1.09 x 0.96 x 1.18 ≈ $x x 1.4200. Therefore a 42% increase in the value has occurred.

questions.text: The inflation rate is predicted to be 3%, 3.5%, 4% and then 5% over the next four years. What would you expect a bicycle costing $500 to cost in four years' time?

An investment of $19,250 is left to accumulate interest over a 4 year period. During the first year the interest paid is 9.2%, and in successive years the rates paid are 8.6%, 8.7% and 8.4%. Find the value of the investment after 4 years.
Caitlin invests 2100 euros in a fund which accumulates interest at 9.5% per annum. If the money is left in the investment for a 5 year period, what will its maturing value be?
An amount of money is invested at 6% for the first year, 11% for the second year, and 7% for the third year. What is the percentage increase in the value of the investment over this period?
A politician's wage increases by 3%, 8%, 5% and then 10% over a four year period. What is the percentage increase in the wage over this period of time?

A share fund reported a 5% increase in value for year 1, a 17% decrease in value for year 2, and 4% increases thereafter. What will be the overall percentage increase or decrease of the share fund over the 5 years?

content.title: Compound Interest
content.content: Section C: COMPOUND INTEREST

content.title: Compound Interest Table
content.content: Table showing compound interest calculation for 5000 euros at 7% annually over 5 years.

content.title: Compound Interest Formula
content.content: The compound interest formula
math: P_v \text{ is the present value or amount initially invested}
i \text{ is the annual interest rate as a decimal}
n \text{ is the number of years of investment}
F_v - P_v \text{ is the total interest earned over the } n \text{ year period}

content.question: $8000 is invested for 3 years at 8% p.a. compound interest with interest paid annually. a) What will it amount to after this period? b) How much interest is earned?

content.title: Finding the Amount to be Invested for a Desired Future Value
content.content: We can use the compound growth formula to find how much we need to invest in order to generate a particular amount in the future.

content.question: How much should I invest now if I require a maturing or future value of $15,000 in 4 years' time? The highest rate of interest I can get is 7.9% p.a. compounded annually, fixed over the period.
content.solution: In this case F_v = 15000, n = 4, and i = 7.9% = 0.079. Now F_v = P_v(1+i)^n, so 15000 = P_v(1.079)^4, therefore P_v = 15000/(1.079)^4 ≈ 11066.38. I would need to invest $11,066.38.

content.title: Calculating the Annual Rate of Investment Growth
content.content: The compound growth formula can be used in non-banking problems to find the average rate at which an investment is growing.

content.question: Stephen Prior bought a rare New Zealand bank note for $4600. He kept it for 4 years and then sold it for $7300 at auction. What annual rate did Stephen's investment return?
(continuation of Example 16)
content.solution: (1+i)^4 = 7300/4600, 1+i = fourth root of (73/46), 1+i ≈ 1.12238, i ≈ 0.12238, i ≈ 12.238%. So, the annual rate of increase was about 12.2%.

content.title: Depreciation Definition
content.content: Depreciation is the process by which goods lose value over time. If a business owns goods that depreciate in value and are essential for the business to earn an income, the taxation department will usually allow the business to claim the depreciation as a tax deduction. Many items are depreciated by a constant percentage for each year of their useful life. They are said to be depreciated on their reduced balance.

content.title: Depreciation Table Example
content.content: Table showing how a video projector costing $8500 depreciates over 3 years at 30% each year.

content.title: Depreciation Formula
content.content: The depreciation formula
math: \text{where } F_v \text{ is the future value after } n \text{ time periods}
P_v \text{ is the original purchase price or present value}
i \text{ is the depreciation rate per period as a decimal}
n \text{ is the number of periods}

content.question: A motorcycle was purchased for 12,500 euros and depreciated at 15% each year. a) Find its value after five years. b) By how much did it depreciate?
math: F_v = P_v(1-i)^n \text{ where } P_v = 12500, i = 0.15, n = 5

content.title: Credit Cards
content.content: Credit cards are a very popular way to borrow money because of their convenience. However, they charge a higher rate of interest than other borrowing alternatives. Suppose we use our credit card to obtain a cash advance. In this case, interest will be charged from the date the advance is made. There is no interest free period. Interest is calculated daily on these advances and is compounded each month.

content.question: Jeri obtained a $1000 cash advance on her credit card on the 8th January. She received her statement for the period ending on the 20th January, then got another cash advance on the 25th January for $500. How much interest will be charged by her next statement on the 20th February? Assume the interest is charged at 16.9% p.a. and compounded monthly.
content.solution: The period 8/1 - 20/1 inclusive is 13 days, so the interest charged = $1000 x 0.169 x 13/365 = $6.02. The interest is now added to the balance, so Jeri now owes $1000.02. The period 21/1 - 24/1 inclusive is 4 days, so the interest charged = $1506.02 x 0.169 x 4/365 = $1.86. This $1.86 is not added until the next statement. The period 25/1 - 20/2 inclusive is 27 days, so the interest charged = $1506.02 x 0.169 x 27/365 = $18.83. So the interest is $6.02 + $1.86 + $18.83 = $26.71. The total interest charged is $26.71.

questions.text: Alma obtains $500 cash advance on her credit card on 17th November. Her statement is issued on 27th November. Calculate the interest charged on the statement if the interest rate is 16.25% p.a.
Bronte obtains a cash advance of $2000 on his credit card on 7th January. He repays it in full on 20th January. Calculate the interest charged on the statement if the interest rate is 16.25% p.a.

Sylva draws advances on her credit card of 500 euros on July 20th and 500 euros on August 12th. Her statement for the period ending on the 24th of each month and the interest rate charged is 18.5% p.a. How much interest is Sylva charged for the period ending on August 24th?

Steve draws advances on his credit card as follows: 30th March - cash advance $180, 18th March - cash advance $300. His statement for the first period ending on the 15th of each month and the interest rate charged is 16.25% p.a. Calculate the total interest charges on the advance for the period ending April 15th.

content.title: Buying on Terms
content.content: When buying an item on terms, the purchaser pays a deposit at the time of the sale, and then the rest of the price at a certain rate over a certain time. The deposit may be cash or else the value of a traded item. The regular payments made to pay off the loan include an interest charge. Electrical items, cars, and whitegoods such as washing machines and refrigerators are often purchased this way.

content.question: A car is priced at $23,850. The terms are 20% deposit and $136.10 per week for 3 years. Calculate: a) the amount borrowed b) the total amount of repayments c) the total interest paid d) the total cost of the car.

solution.b: Total repayments = regular payment x number of payments = $136.10 x 156 = $21,231.60 (3 years x 52 weeks = 156)
solution.c: Interest paid = total repayments - amount borrowed = $21,231.60 - $19,080 = $2151.60
solution.d: Total cost of car = deposit paid + total repayments = $4770 + $21,231.60 = $26,001.60

questions.text: A washing machine is advertised for 1050 euros cash or else 100 euros deposit followed by monthly repayments of 47.50 euros for 24 months. a) What will be the total cost of the machine if it is purchased on terms? b) How much interest will be paid?
A customer purchases a lounge suite costing $5200 by paying a 10% deposit and then $415 per month for 12 months. Calculate: a) the total cost of the lounge suite b) the amount of interest charged.

An electrical appliance store advertises a digital television for 1800 pounds. They offer a discount of 5% if the item is paid for in cash up front, or terms of 20% deposit plus 10% annual flat rate repayments of $64 for one year. How much would you save if you bought the television on terms rather than paying cash?

Kara is moving into a flat and wants to buy a new bed. She chooses a bed for $985 cash or deposit $100 with monthly repayments of $92.50 for 18 months. Store B sells 695 euros cash or deposit 100 euros with monthly repayments of $56.50 for one year. Dealer B, price $818 or 10% deposit with monthly payments of $920 for 4 years. Which dealer should Kara choose?

content.title: Personal Loans
content.content: A common way to borrow money to purchase cars, boats, renovations, overseas holidays, education expenses or share portfolios, is to take out a personal loan. Banks, credit unions and finance companies all offer personal loans with differing terms, conditions, and interest rates. Interest will be the biggest cost involved in repaying a personal loan. Interest is calculated on the reducing balance of the loan so that the interest reduces as the loan is repaid. The interest each period is added to the balance owed and the repayment is deducted.

content.question: $2000 is borrowed at a reducing balance interest rate of 12% p.a. Monthly repayments of $400 are to be made. By completing a table, determine: a) the number of repayments to be made b) the final repayment.

solution.table: An interest rate of 12% p.a. means 1% per month. Month 1: Opening balance $2000.00, Interest $20.00, Repayment $400.00, Reduction in principal $380.00, Closing balance $1620. Month 2: Opening balance $1620.00, Interest $16.20, Repayment $400.00, Reduction in principal $383.80, Closing balance $1236.20. Month 3: Opening balance $1236.20, Interest $12.36, Repayment $400.00, Reduction in principal $387.64, Closing balance $848.56. Month 4: Opening balance $848.56, Interest $8.49, Repayment $400.00, Reduction in principal $391.51, Closing balance $457.05. Month 5: Opening balance $457.05, Interest $4.57, Repayment $400.00, Reduction in principal $395.43, Closing balance $61.62. Month 6: Opening balance $61.62, Interest $0.62, Repayment $62.24, Reduction in principal $61.62, Closing balance $0.00.
solution.a: From the table we can see that there are five full monthly repayments plus a final part payment.
From the table we can see that there are five full monthly repayments plus a final part payment.

questions.text: Set up a table as in Example 20 to describe a loan of $3000. The interest rate is 9% p.a. compounded monthly under reducing balance conditions, and monthly payments of $600 are to be made. How many payments are required to repay the loan?

Erica takes out a loan to buy a car. She borrows 20,000 euros for 5 years at a rate of 12% p.a. compounded monthly under reducing balance conditions. Determine the closing balance after making monthly repayments of 445 euros for three months.

A loan of 100,000 pounds is taken out for 10 years to buy a share portfolio. Interest is charged at 12% p.a. compounded quarterly under reducing balance conditions. Determine the amount still owing after 1 year if quarterly repayments of 4350 pounds are made.

content.title: Loan Repayment Tables
content.content: When you apply for a personal loan, you will be advised of the amount you will need to repay each fortnight or each month. This amount is dependent on the loan amount, the duration of the loan, and the interest rate charged. Banks have tables of repayments for various loans. Loan calculators are available on bank websites. The resulting monthly instalments are rounded off to the next 10 cents. For example, $485.51 becomes $485.60.

content.title: Table of Monthly Repayments
content.content: Table of Monthly Repayments per 1000 units of currency, showing loan terms (12-60 months) and annual interest rates (10.0%-13.0%)

content.question: Erin takes out a personal loan for $16,500 to buy a car. She negotiates a term of 4 years at 11.5% p.a. interest. Calculate the: a) monthly repayments b) total repayments c) interest charged.

solution.a: From the table, the monthly repayments on each $1000 for 4 years (48 months) at 11.5% p.a. = $26.0890. The repayments on $16,500 = $26.0890 x 16.5 = $430.4685 ≈ $430.50 (to next 10 cents). The monthly repayments are $430.50.
solution.b: Total repayments = monthly repayment x number of months = $430.50 x 48 = $20,664. So, $20,664 is repaid in total.
solution.c: Interest = total repayments - amount borrowed = $20,664 - $16,500 = $4164. The total interest charged is $4164.

questions.text: Ron takes out a personal loan for 15,000 euros to go overseas. He will repay it over 5 years at 11.5% p.a. Calculate the: a) monthly repayments b) total repayments c) interest charged.
Jai and Tatiana need 18,000 pounds to fund house renovations. They take out a personal loan over 3 years at 13% p.a. Calculate the: a) monthly repayments b) total repayments c) interest charged.

Gunter needs 28,000 euros to buy a boat. His bank offers him a personal loan at 12.5% p.a. Calculate the total interest he will pay if he repays it over: a) 2 years b) 5 years. Comment on your answers.

Trina wants to borrow $45,000 to purchase some shares. Calculate the total interest charged for the following options: a) Balance Bank offer 11.5% over 5 years b) Cash Credit Union offer 12.5% over 3 years. Which option would you recommend for Trina?

parts.label: b

parts.label: c

questions.text: A lounge suite was bought for a basic cost of $1780. It was marked up for a 30% profit, and then 10% GST was added on. Determine the final selling price of the lounge suite.

Business equipment purchased for 25,000 euros depreciates at 17.5% p.a. Calculate the value of the equipment when the company 'closed down five years after the investment period. What would be the maturing value of an investment of $20,000 for 6 years?

A new car costing 15,000 euros depreciates at a rate of 10% p.a. What is the value of the car in 5 years' time?

A 2000 loan has an interest rate of 18% p.a. and is reducible monthly. If 600 euros is repaid each month, draw up a loan schedule to find: a) the number of repayments necessary b) the size of the last repayment.

Terri wants to buy a car priced at 24,990 euros. She does not have the full amount saved and is therefore offered the option of paying a 30% deposit and $75.50 per week over 5 years. If she takes up this option, determine: a) the deposit she pays b) the total amount she pays for the vehicle c) the amount of interest she pays.

Mirumi takes out a personal loan for 600,000 yen to go on a holiday. Her bank offers her a rate of 11% p.a. over 3 years on a reducing balance basis. Calculate her: a) monthly repayments using the table of monthly repayments on page 263 b) total repayments c) interest charged.

parts.label: b
parts.text: An item of clothing is marked at $49 but sold in a 15% discount sale. Find the sale price.

questions.text: The value of a rare stamp increases by 70% one year, but the next year it decreases in value by 35%. What is its overall percentage change in value?
A lounge suite was bought for a basic cost of $1780. It was marked up for a 30% profit, and then 10% GST was added on. Determine the final selling price of the lounge suite.
Business equipment purchased for 25,000 euros depreciates at 17.5% p.a. Calculate the value of the equipment when the company closed down five years after purchase.

A bank offers an investment package to its customers of 7.4% p.a. with interest paid annually, provided no money is withdrawn during the investment period. What would be the maturing value of an investment of $20,000 for 6 years?

A company car is purchased for 60,500 euros. Depreciation is calculated at 17.5% of the book value each year. a) What is the book value of the car after four years? b) By what amount has the car depreciated after four years?

A 6000 euro car is purchased with a deposit of 15,000 yen. The balance is repaid over 5 years at 10.5% per annum on a reducing balance. Calculate: a) the amount borrowed b) the size of each monthly repayment c) the total to be repaid d) the amount of interest paid.

formulas.description: Total interest earned over the investment period

formulas.name: Depreciation Formula
formulas.description: Future value calculation for depreciation where F_v is future value, P_v is present value, i is depreciation rate as decimal, n is number of periods

formulas.name: Outstanding Balance (Loans)
formulas.description: Calculate remaining balance on a reducing balance loan

formulas.name: Amount Borrowed (Terms)
formulas.description: Calculate amount financed when buying on terms
